First. determine what the hypothesis will predict will happen in a new situation. Then design an experiment (if possible) to the test the predicitions. Be sure the experimental design is a free of technical error and human bias as much as possible. Use controls. Reproduce the experiment several times by yourself and if possible by others. If the prediction of hypothesis are correct. The hypothesis can be called a scientific theory (although other scientists will like to see may more predictions proven correct.) If the predictions are not correct, one needs to go back and review the original hypothesis for modification or replacement and repeat the tests. There are certain predictions that cannot be tested with experiments (at least not yet). However, hypothesis can make predictions about future observations of phenomena (like the location of a planet at a certain time in the Soler System). Then the test of the hypotheses will involve careful observation of the location of the planet in the sky. The statistical procedures described by Mr. Srinivasan V are very helpful when the data from the experiment is not robust. When I did biochemical experiments, the data was usually very clear. The experiment worked or it did not work, Repeated trials gave very similar results. Only standard deviations and error bars for data on graphs were needed. I used more elaborate statistics in only a few cases. There is a tendency to over use statistics. It can be a waste of time. But always discuss whether to use statistics with your experiments with your teacher, mentor, or supervisor.
